⚡️After What Not To Wear ended, Trinny Woodall faced money worries and the dramatic death of her ex-husband. So how did she turn it all around?

🛍️ Unlike Cinderella, Woodall’s isn’t a rags to riches tale, but a riches to rags to riches one. 

Read more about @trinnywoodall’s success with @trinnylondon here👇

🗣️ When that ran out, I sold some more clothes, then sold my house, because I couldn’t afford the mortgage. It did take balls – it was very scary. But I knew I had no alternative. Nobody becomes a great entrepreneur from a place of comfort

🔴But before the business took off Woodall had to make sacrifices for the business 

 I couldn’t afford to live in the house I was living in, so I rented it out, and sold quite a few of my clothes

🗣️ What helped us a lot is that women didn’t want to stop buying things to make them feel better... having that time was so very precious. You needed that time just to do something for you. That’s what I was doing,  says Woodall

🛍️At the start of the pandemic, the company employed 68 people; now, it employs 200. 

It sells 187 products in 200 countries, with the £26 Miracle Blur primer selling every 60 seconds. 

Skincare was only launched in February, but already accounts for almost a third of sales

📈Lockdown might have spelt disaster for many businesses, but not Woodall’s.

Between March 2020 to January 2021, the brand grew by 280 percent , delivering £44 million in gross revenue in the year to March 2021

🚶‍♀️ Woodall eschews using models on her website in favour of featuring real’ women of all ages, including 40s to 80s.  

 Her fans, known as Trinny’s Tribe’, lap up her honesty, and love that she’ll talk as openly about her bowel movements as she will about her blusher

🛍️Launched in 2017, Trinny London’s success is down to an alchemical mix of clever products and innovative tech, all driven by its charismatic founder whose enthusiastic social media presence is a powerful driver of sales

👉 Like Belle, she is clad in yellow. Like Rapunzel, she has really good hair. Like Snow White, she has lips as red as a rose. 

 Unlike those hapless three, she doesn’t need to be rescued. For Woodall is her own heroine and the skilled author of her own fairy tale

✍️ There is something of the Disney princess about Trinny Woodall as she strides towards me in the shiny Chelsea HQ of @trinnylondon, her beauty empire that in five scant years has gone from struggling to find investors to being valued at £180 million,  writes @LauraCraik

Gallop reveals the rest of her findings in the full story 👇

❓Was it done elsewhere, or by someone else, possibly for some symbolic reason, perhaps even linked with the Masonic lodge he was involved with?

Sometimes the lodge was called Propaganda Due or P2, at other times i frati neri, the black friars’…
➡️ And there was another question Gallop was unable to answer: Calvi had always had a moustache, yet his face had been clean-shaven

🗣  What I discovered was that, with the tide ebbing – as it was at the time when Calvi seemed likely to have been suspended from the rope – it would have been relatively straightforward to bring a vessel in on the same side of the scaffolding as the body was found,  Gallop says

➡️ With the murder routes, Calvi could have been transported to the bridge – incapacitated or even dead – either in a car, in which case he could have been carried to the towpath then down the ladder on to the scaffolding, or lowered on to it over the river wall; or by boat

🔴 Next, Gallop turned her attention to the two most likely murder routes’.

 I treated as open the question of whether he could have been incapacitated, or even dead, before he was brought to the scaffolding,  she writes
➡️ What became apparent was that the two possible suicide routes’ to reach the scaffolding were both highly implausible

✍️ Gallop writes:  This reconstruction showed me how hard it would have been for an unfit 62-year-old man to reach the place on the scaffolding where Calvi’s body was found, all on his own – with broken bricks in his pockets and in the crotch of his trousers

➡️  So I arranged to have it erected in my garden and persuaded my husband, Russell – who is roughly the same build as Calvi  – to dress up in some clothing that the Calvi family had provided,  Gallop adds.
✍️ Gallop writes:  To determine how he died, I had to work out whether it was possible for Calvi to have climbed on to the scaffolding unassisted

💬 My first piece of good fortune in the investigation came with the scaffolding,  writes Gallop.

 In some cold cases I have worked on, important items have been lost, but amazingly, the scaffolding had been kept intact by the firm that erected it

The foreshore under Blackfriars Bridge is always underwater and the builders’ scaffolding from which his body had been found hanging had long gone.

Any marks made on the bridge’s structure would have been washed away or merged with other unconnected marks made since

🗣️ One of the first things I did was to visit the scene, standard when a crime has just been committed, but this was a whole decade on,  Gallop writes.

 The visit was useful in a general sense, but unsurprisingly there was nothing specific to learn there

🔎There had been very little crime-scene-type investigation.

All Gallop had to work on was a few paltry pieces of evidence: including the jacket, trousers and shoes he had been wearing; the rope from around his neck; and the broken pieces of brick that had been in his pockets

➡️ A decade later, the Calvi family approached Angela Gallop.

What they wanted above all was closure around the question of whether he had killed himself (as a first London inquest had concluded) or been murdered in a way that was designed to look like suicide

🔴 The police had almost immediately decided Calvi’s death was suicide.

His family, however, instinctively rejected the notion that such a devout Catholic as Roberto Calvi would ever have taken his own life, since suicide is considered a mortal sin in traditional Catholicism
➡️ Four decades on, many key questions remain unanswered, and no one has ever been convicted of involvement in his demise

🔴 Roberto Calvi was the chairman of Italian bank Banco Ambrosiano.

Days before Calvi’s death, Banco Ambrosiano had collapsed with debts of up to £800 million; the previous year, Calvi had been found guilty of illegal currency transactions, but he was released pending appeal

👑The Queen, unable to watch it in person at the age of 96, was ably represented by the rest of her family, who clapped, waved and - in the case of Prince Louis - roared like lions at the weird and wonderful sights before them
🎶As Ed Sheeran performed his song Perfect, images of the Queen in all her glory - at the heart of her happy marriage and young family - were beamed to audiences

👑The fourth and final, the moment the crowds had really been waiting for, saw footage of the Queen and Prince Philip in all their glorious happiness beamed to the world, before the Royal Family appeared on the Buckingham Palace balcony once more

Flags in all colours of the rainbow poured down The Mall, with dancers and roller skaters carrying messages of hope for the planet.

The next section turned the Queen’s personal favourites into puppets of various life-like quality, from trotting corgis to horses mounted on bikes

👑A third act, the most colourful by far, saw a carnival-esque run-through of the key themes of the Queen’s reign: her coronation, her wedding to Prince Philip represented in a  big fat Bollywood wedding  and  unity , depicted through the medium of circus performers

🌟The Noughties brought the Hairy Bikers, Gok Wan and Holly Willoughby.

One bus, crammed full of children’s television characters from the Gruffalo, to Wallace and Gromit and Iggle Piggle, inspired enthusiastic waves from the small Cambridge children and their cousins

🚗They were followed by  Dames in Jags , bringing a regal air - until one broke down.

Dame Prue Leith’s Jaguar shuddered to a halt, pushed by four energetic stewards in high vis jackets as she redoubled her waving efforts

🌟The arrival of the 1980s brought Rubik’s cubes and a Pac-Man walking in procession, joined by aerobics instructors in leotards.

True glamour came on the 1990s bus, with supermodels Naomi Campbell and Kate Moss, wearing a Union flag jacket, reliving their early careers

🚌Alan Titchmarsh, Tony Blackburn and Basil Brush joined the 1960s bus.

Into the 1970s, there came hula hoops, roller skaters and gold full-body leotards, with a bus containing Dame Esther Rantzen, Debbie McGee, Noddy Holder

🌟Next, it was a decade-by-decade breakdown, as celebrities of varying degrees of fame took to buses.

A first bus blaring music from the 1950s with Sir Cliff Richard, turning up to his fourth Jubilee like the consummate showbiz professional he is, on the microphone

2⃣The second act could hardly have been a sharper change of pace.

🚲A handful of star cyclists including Sir Chris Hoy and Sir Jason and Dame Laura Kenny cycled casually along the route, which had been swept clear moments after the departure of the horses

🟡The Gold State Coach, accompanied by the Sovereign’s Escort, was the centrepiece, gleaming even in the cloudy weather with footage of the radiant Queen at her coronation so realistic some members of the public waved

🎖️Service men and women in a uniformed sea of red and gold progressed down The Mall.

The military section included 770 soldiers from the British Army, 420 representing the Royal Air Force, and 200 from the Royal Navy and Royal Marines, each moving at 116 paces per minute
1⃣ First came the military, in the faultless pomp and ceremony spectators have become so used to it is easy to forget the countless hours of meticulous rehearsal that make it so
👑 It was, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge said afterwards, a  joyous occasion , bringing together the best of Britain in all its forms to tell the story of 70 years

🌟 Crowds flocked in their droves to line the streets of London in part respect and part curiosity, as the spectacle of the final Platinum Jubilee celebration wended its way past in all-singing, all-dancing, all hula-hooping form

🌟Celebrities in open-topped buses, scampering puppet corgis and a Gold State Coach – this Jubilee parade honoured the greatest of them all

🇬🇧Even the staunchest royalists would admit, it was also a little eccentric

The largest puppet of its kind to be solely human-operated, she is animated by a rotating team of 30 puppeteers with 15 moving the dragon at any one time

🔴What happens next?

🔴Can’t the UK leave the ECHR?

We could, but doing so would have ramifications for Brexit agreements with the EU.

It would also bring reputational damage to the UK, which played a key role in setting up the Council of Europe and the ECHR after the war

🔴How can this happen after Brexit?

The Council of Europe is not an EU body. 

🇪🇺While the UK left the EU with Brexit, it stayed part of the Council of Europe, which was founded after the Second World War to uphold democracy, the rule of law and human rights

🔴What do British courts say?

On Monday, the UK Supreme Court threw out a bid by campaigners to stop the flight for Rwanda from going ahead. 

A judicial review into the legality of the Rwanda policy will be held in six weeks
➡️The Court has the power to make binding judgement and decisions in the UK, which can override decisions made by British courts and order the government to pay compensation.

🔴What is the European Court of Human Rights?

The court is the legal arm of the Council of Europe and is based in Strasbourg, France.

It interprets the European Convention on Human Rights, which is given force in the UK as part of the Human Rights Act
➡️The ECHR told the Government that the man, named only as KN, should not be removed until three weeks after the final domestic court decision in a judicial review into his deportation

It is one of the first times Mr Johnson has explicitly linked the timing of major tax cuts to inflation, reflecting changes in his thinking after briefings with leading UK economists.

🔓 This front page story is currently free to read

Discussing calls to cut tax, Mr Johnson told LBC on Monday:  Yes, of course I understand that we need to bear down on taxation and we certainly will. 

🗣️ But he said there was an  inflationary spike that we’ve got to get through right now
That poses a major economic challenge, because traditionally the policy moves to curb increasing prices are the opposite of those adopted to overcome stuttering growth.

The UK economy shrunk by 0.3 per cent in April, the Office for National Statistics said on Monday - the second successive drop in GDP, following a 0.1 per cent fall in March.

➡️ The news fuelled fears that the UK economy could be heading into recession

Boris Johnson is not planning to cut taxes for households until inflation is brought under control, meaning action is unlikely before next year.

Downing Street and the Treasury fear soaring prices could  spiral , even further if a tax cut is adopted to ease the cost of living

🔺During the pandemic, sleeplessness has more than doubled, from 20 percent  of the population to more than 40 percent

Read about the other ways you can kick snack cravings here 👇

💤Studies show also that an absence of high-quality sleep results in an increased level of the hunger hormone ghrelin and a reduced level of leptin (the hormone that makes us feel full).

Which means that we are likely to feel more hungry and to snack or crave certain things

🍦 If we had fewer cues to snack, or were pushed to buy fewer high-calorie snacks, we should be able to see real change. Rather than putting the burden on consumers, our food environments need to change so it’s easier for us to eat more healthily,  continue Harper

🍩But  humans are very susceptible to messaging and suggestion around food and our environment has a real impact on what we eat, from adverts and supermarket promotions to what’s available in our local corner shop,  says Hugo Harper, director of the health team at charity Nesta

🧍Biggs says women of childbearing age are also more likely to experience cravings due to the menstrual cycle. 

 Hormones directly speak to the brain and this dictates our appetite,  she says
🧬 Our mood can influence the levels of ghrelin – also known as the hunger hormone – in our body, as well as how much dopamine  and serotonin we produce,  continues Biggs
🗣️ While it is true we associate certain foods with certain feelings and may seek to recreate those through eating them, there are also biological association

❓What causes craving?

 When we have a craving for a certain food, there is something biological going on,  says registered dietician Lola Biggs.  

 Giving in to a craving is not just a matter of not having enough willpower; they are driven by different physiological factors

📈Nesta, a charity working for social change, calculated that an extra 240 calories a day (the equivalent of an average  grab bag  sized packet of crisps, usually 45-50g) over the course of a year would result in a weight gain of 6.4kg – or a stone

🍿Snacking certainly has an effect on our waistlines.

 A 2018 study by Louisiana State University found that they are responsible for as much as 11 percent  of eating behaviour and weight gain

🥪Whether it’s a salty bacon sandwich the morning after one too many, a chocolate bar to see you through the dreaded 4pm energy slump, snacking and food cravings are part of daily life for many.

⚡️ The Jehovah’s Witness scandal: exposing the shocking stories of abuse

When the elders approached Stewart about Michelle’s abuse, he confessed.

Stewart vowed that he would not harm another child, and the elders, wrongly, believed him.

Read the investigation in full here 👇

Child sexual abuse is one of the most horrific crimes imaginable. Cases are not uncommon within religious groups. 

But what is particularly shocking about what happened to Michelle is the way the Jehovah’s Witnesses dealt with it
Michelle finds it very hard to revisit what happened, but she has agreed to talk to The Telegraph for our investigative podcast, Call Bethel ⤵️

But Stewart’s affable public persona was very unlike the person he became when they were alone. 

🗣️ He would suggest that they finish their knocks early. Then he would take her back to his car or his house and assault her

🔴 Peter Stewart was a ministerial servant’, one of the lower rungs in the hierarchical ladder of a Jehovah Witness congregation, and described in the organisation’s literature as spiritually- minded, reliable, and conscientious men’
She was unfazed by doors closing in her face, but she learnt to dread the time alone with the man who more often than not partnered up with her

For many people reading this, their experience of Jehovah’s Witnesses will be as one of those strangers, opening a front door to be greeted by a pair of neatly dressed individuals bearing copies of The Watchtower. 

For Michelle, these sessions were traumatic... 👇

When she wasn’t at meetings, Michelle would go on field service’ – the Jehovah’s Witness practice of going door to door. 

➡️ She would pair up with another, older Jehovah’s Witness and together they would urge the strangers who answered their knocks to join the organisation

On the outskirts of the Midlands town where Michelle grew up is a low, beige building set back from the road. 

It’s an old Kingdom Hall – the Jehovah’s Witness equivalent of a church – and when Michelle was a child, she would spend many hours a week here at religious meetings

Read the full story 👇

➡️ Sunday’s results also have international implications as Macron, who has been a key negotiating figure between Ukraine and Russia, now faces increasing pressure to prioritise his domestic agenda over foreign policy

🗳️ Melenchon’s party won over voters with a policy agenda that promised to focus on issues at home, including lowering the retirement age from 62 to 60, freezing energy prices amidst rising inflation, and increasing the monthly minimum wage to €1,500 (£1,287)

🔴 While Melenchon’s party didn’t take away Macron’s overall majority, at the very least Sunday’s results mean Macron’s party will likely have to make a series of compromises over the next five years.

That’s a big upset for the president’s pro-business domestic agenda

📈 Headed by the far-left firebrand Jean-Luc Mélenchon, who came in third place in April’s presidential elections, Nupes was projected to take 149 seats, an impressive showing for what is France’s first-left wing coalition since 1997

➡️ The upset comes less than two months after Macron was reelected president against the far-right leader Marine Le Pen of the National Rally party.

Preliminary results projecting her party would take 89 seats, eleven times more seats than the party won in 2017
🔴 One of Macron’s options to seize power back would be to form a coalition with another party, such as the centre-right Les Republicains, which was projected to take 78 seats

🗳️ Early reports on Sunday projected that Macron’s centrist Ensemble (Together) alliance won 224 seats in lower parliament, enough to keep an overall majority.

However, it is still short of the 289 seats it needed to keep the absolute majority in the 577-seat National Assembly

🔴 Macron will now struggle to push forward with his ambitious national agenda.

His greatest challenge this time around came from the newly formed left-green alliance, the New Popular, Environmental, and Social Union, or NUPES coalition

⚡️ Why everything we know about breakfast is wrong

However, if ­nothing on earth is going to come between you and your brekkie, the best advice is to choose a healthy, balanced one that will deliver a good hit of nutrition and sustained energy.

We have five healthy breakfast swaps to make now ⤵️

✅ Its true.

Studies suggest that skipping breakfast, or at least shifting it to 11am to create an overnight fasting ­window of at least 14 hours, could help people to lose four to 11 pounds of weight over several months

❓ True or false

Skipping breakfast can help you lose weight?

❌ Its false...

Researchers say fasting can help restore and rejuvenate your organs. 

If you do habitually skip breakfast it’s important to pay attention to your nutrient intake at other meals to ensure you are getting adequate nutrition

❓ True or false

Breakfast is the most important meal of the day?

✅ Its true!

Many are comprised of simple carbohydrates, like toast and jam or shop-bought cereals, which will cause blood sugar levels to rise sharply rather than provide slow, sustained energy

❓ True or false

Traditional breakfast foods are bad for your health

Heres everything we know about the Polio virus ⤵️
Read the full report from @sarahknapton ⤵️

🦠On rare occasions Polio can infect the spinal cord and the base of the brain, causing paralysis, usually in the legs, that develops over hours or days.

If the breathing muscles are affected, it can be life threatening.

💉Although the odd vaccine-derived polio virus is picked up each year in Britain’s sewage, this latest virus has mutated over time and is now classified as a vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2, which behaves more like wild polio

🧼Polio can be spread by poor hand hygiene and, less commonly, through coughing and sneezing. 

The virus multiplies in the intestine and infected people excrete large quantities of virus in their faeces for several weeks

💉On Wednesday, the UK Health and Security Agency announced that a vaccine-derived polio virus had been detected in sewage from North and East London in February and April, suggesting there had been spread between individuals
🔴Britain was proclaimed polio-free in 2003 and the last wild case was detected in 1984, making the current outbreak the first transmission event since the 1980s
